newsitem.title: GEORGIA: Ex-Soviet Georgia may tender manganese reserves.
newsitem.headline: Ex-Soviet Georgia may tender manganese reserves.

text.p: The former Soviet republic of Georgia may hold an international tender to develop its large manganese deposits and is talking to South Africa's Samancor, the government's press service said on Thursday.

"Samancor representatives have expressed their proposals on cooperating with AO Chiaturmarganets, with the goal of exports of production to world markets," said Giga Chogovadze of the state chancellery's economic section.
He said the Georgian manganese producer needed $20-30 million in investments.
Joint stock company Chiaturmarganets is based at the Chiatur mining and metallurgical complex in western Georgia. The state has a 73 percent stake in the firm.
The complex is home to an ore base with manganese reserves of over 202 million tonnes.
Chiaturmarganets produced 15,000 tonnes of manganese concentrates last year, far below the 1.7-1.8 million tonnes achieved in the Soviet era.
It accounts for about 25 percent of the former Soviet Union's manganese production.
